sub_topic: Calculation of the mass of a substance deposited or dissolved during an electrochemical reaction
message_1: What mass of silver (Ag) will be deposited on a cathode when a current of 0.5 A is passed through a silver nitrate (AgNO3) solution for 30 minutes? The molar mass of silver is 107.87 g/mol and the Faraday constant is 96,485 C/mol.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the following formula:

mass of Ag = (current × time × molar mass of Ag) / (n × Faraday constant)

where:
- current = 0.5 A
- time = 30 minutes = 1800 seconds (since 1 minute = 60 seconds)
- molar mass of Ag = 107.87 g/mol
- n = number of electrons involved in the redox reaction (for silver, n = 1, as Ag+ + 1e- → Ag)
- Faraday constant = 96,485 C/mol

Now, we can plug in the values:

mass of Ag = (0.5 A × 1800 s × 107.87 g/mol) / (1 × 96,485 C/mol)

mass of Ag = (963,330 g·s/mol) / (96,485 C/mol)

mass of Ag ≈ 9.98 g

So, approximately 9.98 grams of silver will be deposited on the cathode.
